unnormalised: Why do people still use 'www' in website addresses? Is it some kind of weird flex?
normalised: Why do people still use 'W-W-W' in website addresses? Is it some kind of weird flex?

unnormalised: Okay, so, let's clear this up, fam. You see "www" and think "world wide web," right? You're not wrong, but it's kinda like saying "ATM machine" - technically correct, but kinda redundant. Back in the day, like '90s internet, the "www" was crucial because it told the server *which* service you wanted from the website. Without it, who knows, you might accidentally end up downloading a file on someone's dial-up connection. Horror! Think of it as specifying you want the *website* part, not just some random FTP server hanging out on the same IP address.
normalised: Okay, so, let's clear this up, fam. You see "W-W-W" and think "world wide web," right? You're not wrong, but it's kinda like saying "A-T-M machine" - technically correct, but kinda redundant. Back in the day, like nineties internet, the "W-W-W" was crucial because it told the server *which* service you wanted from the website. Without it, who knows, you might accidentally end up downloading a file on someone's dial-up connection. Horror! Think of it as specifying you want the *website* part, not just some random F-T-P server hanging out on the same I-P address.

unnormalised: Nowadays, most browsers and websites are smart enough to figure things out without the "www." They automatically redirect you, like a well-trained auto-rickshaw driver in Bangalore who knows exactly where you want to go even if you just mumble vaguely. So, using "www" is kinda like still using a floppy disk – nostalgic, maybe, but definitely not necessary. In fact, most modern web developers will tell you that using "www" adds unnecessary complexity to your website setup, and they'll likely roll their eyes at you if you insist on keeping it.
normalised: Nowadays, most browsers and websites are smart enough to figure things out without the "W-W-W." They automatically redirect you, like a well-trained auto-rickshaw driver in Bangalore who knows exactly where you want to go even if you just mumble vaguely. So, using "W-W-W" is kinda like still using a floppy disk – nostalgic, maybe, but definitely not necessary. In fact, most modern web developers will tell you that using "W-W-W" adds unnecessary complexity to your website setup, and they'll likely roll their eyes at you if you insist on keeping it.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: using "www" is like wearing a full saree to a Goa beach party. Sure, you *can*, but everyone will wonder why. It's not inherently *wrong,* but it's definitely out of place and makes you look a bit...dated. Most sites these days don't require it and auto-redirect. So when you type in 'google.com' instead of 'www.google.com', it's doing some magic in the background.
normalised: Think of it like this: using "W-W-W" is like wearing a full saree to a Goa beach party. Sure, you *can*, but everyone will wonder why. It's not inherently *wrong,* but it's definitely out of place and makes you look a bit...dated. Most sites these days don't require it and auto-redirect. So when you type in 'google dot com' instead of 'W-W-W dot google dot com', it's doing some magic in the background.

unnormalised: So, next time you're typing in a website address, feel free to ditch the "www." Your fingers (and my sense of internet history) will thank you. Unless you're visiting some ancient website designed by someone who still thinks Netscape Navigator is the hottest browser in town, in that case, maybe just humour them with the "www." You know, for old time's sake.
normalised: So, next time you're typing in a website address, feel free to ditch the "W-W-W." Your fingers (and my sense of internet history) will thank you. Unless you're visiting some ancient website designed by someone who still thinks Netscape Navigator is the hottest browser in town, in that case, maybe just humour them with the "W-W-W." You know, for old time's sake.
